rsbNotes.title: Ps 32
rsbNotes.text: Ps. 32 A penitential psalm containing some distinctive wisdom language (vv. 1, 2, 8–10).

rsbNotes.title: Ps 32:2
rsbNotes.text: 32:2 iniquity. Three different words for sin are used in the first two verses to bring out the many aspects of man’s rebellion against God. Paul cites the first two verses of this psalm in Rom. 4:6–8 in describing the grace of God’s forgiveness.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 32:3
rsbNotes.text: 32:3 my bones wasted away. The psalmist perceives sin’s consequences in his body. This is not merely poetic language, although sin does not always have immediate physical consequences.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 32:4
rsbNotes.text: 32:4 my strength was . . . heat. Guilt immobilized and enervated the psalmist.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 32:5
rsbNotes.text: 32:5 I acknowledged my sin to you. He praises God’s willingness and authority to forgive.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 32:6
rsbNotes.text:
32:6 godly. Or “saints”; see Ps. 31:23 note.

great waters. Elsewhere translated “many waters.” See notes Ps. 18:4, 16; 29:3, 10; 46:2; 69:1, 2; 144:7.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 32:8
rsbNotes.text: 32:8 I will instruct you. Using language found in wisdom sections of the Old Testament (e.g., Ps. 1 and Prov. 1–9), God promises to direct the psalmist in the way of the covenant, in the way of righteousness.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 32:9
rsbNotes.text: 32:9 like a horse. Horses and mules do the will of their masters only under compulsion (Prov. 26:3). The righteous should obey out of love and gratitude to their God.
